title: Bilateral Otosclerosis Post-Stapedectomy with Dizziness
chief_complaint: I have constant buzzing and ringing in my right ear, and I feel off-balance when I move my head. My hearing improved after my surgeries years ago, so I'm mostly concerned about the dizziness.

problem_summary.onset: History of bilateral otosclerosis with surgeries completed approximately 4 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Hearing reported as significantly improved and stable since revision surgery; recent onset of dizziness.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant tinnitus in the right ear (steady buzzing/ringing); dizziness described as being off-balance with head movement.
problem_summary.functional_impact: No significant communication difficulties reported at this time.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Primary goal is to address dizziness; monitoring hearing stability.

history.present_illness: Patient reports history of bilateral otosclerosis. Stapedectomy and revision were completed for each ear. Last surgery was on the left ear ~4 years ago.
history.otologic_history: Bilateral stapedectomies and revisions. Father had hearing loss but no surgery.
history.noise_exposure_history: No significant history of noise exposure.
history.medical_psych_history: Report of dizziness/off-balance sensation with head movement.
history.prior_management: Last hearing test 4 years ago (results unavailable).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight sloping to mild mixed loss (250-1000 Hz), sloping to moderate-to-severe (2000-4000 Hz). Left ear: Slight SNHL (250-500 Hz), rising to normal (1000-2000 Hz), sloping to moderate mixed loss (4000-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured due to a history of otosurgery.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a complex mixed hearing loss profile following bilateral stapedectomies. The Right ear shows a mild-to-severe mixed loss, while the Left ear retains largely normal hearing sensitivity in the low-to-mid frequencies, dropping to a mixed loss in the high frequencies. Despite the thresholds, speech recognition ability remains excellent in both ears.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows that the surgery on your left ear has maintained good hearing in the main speech pitches, which explains why you aren't having trouble communicating.
The dizziness you are experiencing appears to be Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) affecting the left side.
We recommend following up with the ENT specialist to manage the BPPV.
Since you are doing well communicating, hearing aids are not urgent, but we should monitor your hearing annually.
If you become interested in amplification for the right ear or if hearing changes, please return to the clinic.
notes_for_actor: You are not currently struggling to hear conversations in quiet environments because your left ear is functioning well.
